Headline.Para: Schools here referred 900 students who needed help to social workers last year

LeadPara.Para: SINGAPORE - Something was eating the primary school girl.

When she confided in her school counsellor that she was afraid of her older brother because he had been rough with her, the school alerted Fei Yue Community Services' Family Service Centre in Choa Chu Kang.

TailParas.Para: Social worker Lin Feng was then roped in to investigate because the school feared there could be other incidents of violence in the girl's home. But Mr Lin learnt it was a one-off incident and the teenage boy had kicked his sister during an argument. Even then, their parents were alerted, to prevent a repeat of the incident.
The girl's school knew what to do, thanks to a protocol which helps them decide how and when to refer schoolchildren, and their families, to family service centres and social service offices.

Family service centres are run by charities and they provide counselling and other aid to families, while social service offices are Government-run and administer Government financial aid schemes to the needy.

The Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF) is boosting the delivery of social services through more information sharing and better co-ordination between agencies, to ensure the needy get appropriate help. One such initiative involves the referral protocol which schools can use to refer students and their families to social workers in their community.
MSF Minister Desmond Lee said earlier this month (March 7) the referral protocol was jointly developed with the Education Ministry (MOE). It was first piloted at the end of 2014.

The two ministries had been exploring ways to boost the support given to schoolchildren from vulnerable families who could be facing multiple problems and were in need of support from various agencies.

The students included those from broken homes - ranging from absentee parents to those with strained ties among loved ones - to families facing financial strife. Some of the youth also showed anti-social behaviour.

Once such a child is identified, the schools would contact their parents to get the consent to refer them to a family service centre. The centre would then work with the family to learn about their challenges and find ways to alleviate or cope with it.
To date, 208 schools have adopted the referral protocol which will be rolled out to all schools by the end of the year (2018).
Last year (2017), schools referred about 900 cases to family service centres and social service offices to address parenting and financial issues, and youth behavioural problems.

The referral protocol is part of the MSF's move to boost the delivery of social services so that the needy can get appropriate help. Among other things, this can be achieved through more sharing of information between agencies and better co-ordination of services, Mr Lee told Parliament during the debate on his ministry's budget earlier this month.

Over at the Sengkang Family Service Centre, social workers say they often get referrals involving students who play truant, with some having skipped school up to a few months at a stretch. In many cases, they learnt that problems at home contributed to the truancy.
For example, the family may have been forced to move often, sometimes squeezing in with relatives and friends, because they do not have their own home due to financial problems.
Ms Esther Ng, the centre's assistant senior social worker, said: "These families are beset by so many problems and without guidance, going to school for the child may not be a priority."

The referral protocol is also useful as it sets common standards. That way, everyone in the system - from school staff to social workers in the community - knows what to do when they come across a student who needs help, said Mr Ian Peterson, cluster director of family and community services at Care Corner Singapore.
With better co-ordination between schools and family service centres, morefamilies can be saved from falling through the cracks, he added.

Mr Calvin Ho, a social worker from Fei Yue's Choa Chu Kang Family Service Centre, said the referral protocol enables problems to be detected earlier, adding: "We want to intervene at an earlier stage, to address and arrest problems as early as possible to prevent it from worsening."
